etymologies: 1970s (originally in Hawaiian English): origin uncertain; perhaps from Japanese shaka, a name for the Buddha (though if this is the case, the relationship with the gesture is unclear)

definitions: a hand gesture in which the thumb and little finger are extended outward from a closed fist, used when greeting or parting from someone or to express approval, solidarity, etc.

examples.text: the President left with a grin and a shaka sign
he didn't know who the guy was, but still gave a shaka and said “nice voice”

shortDefinitions: hand gesture in which thumb and little finger are extended from fist

definitions: used to express approval, solidarity, etc., often when greeting or parting from someone

examples.text: “Shaka, brah.” He high-fived Lopaka, then broke into laughter
